prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement despite the wife's suggestion. The wife is now struggling with managing the kids, chores, and her own work because the husband is in the bedroom. She's saying that the husband is the one at fault for not moving his office to the basement, while the husband thinks she's the problem for not keeping quiet.

First, I need to analyze the responsibilities here. The husband chose to work from the bedroom, which is a shared space, even though there's a quieter alternative available (the basement). By choosing to work there, he's creating a situation where the wife has to manage everything else without being able to use the same space freely. The wife is working from home and taking on most household chores and childcare, which is a lot already. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom is causing her to have limited use of the space, affecting her ability to work and take care of things.

The key points here are about mutual respect and consideration. The husband's preference for the view might be valid, but it's causing significant disruption to the wife's life. The wife tried to suggest a better alternative (the basement), which he rejected. Now, he's expecting her to manage the household without disturbing him, but his choice of workspace is the root of the problem. It seems like the husband isn't being considerate of her needs, which are equally important.

The user initially thought the author (the wife) is in the wrong but wants to know if that's accurate. But based on the scenario, the husband's decision to work in the bedroom is the main issue. The wife is justified in pointing out that his choice is causing the disruption. Therefore, the husband is more at fault here. So the answer should be B (the author is not in the wrong).
